subject: Art
title: Reading Histograms
description: The graph that shows you exactly how your exposure looks ‚Äî don't guess, read.

hook.text: Your camera's LCD lies ‚Äî brightness changes with screen settings and ambient light. The histogram never lies. It's a graph showing the distribution of tones from dark (left) to bright (right). Learn to read it and you'll nail exposure.

buildup.text: Left side = shadows. Right side = highlights. Height = number of pixels at that brightness. Data pushed against the left wall = crushed blacks (detail lost). Data against the right wall = blown highlights (detail lost).

discovery.text: No single 'correct' histogram shape: a dark scene legitimately has data on the left. A bright scene has data on the right. The warning sign is data CRASHING into either wall ‚Äî that's clipped, unrecoverable information.

twist.text: 'Expose to the right' (ETTR): slightly overexpose without clipping highlights. This maximizes data quality because sensors capture more information in bright tones. Then darken in post-processing for clean shadows.

climax.text: Enable the histogram on your camera. Take three shots of the same scene: one underexposed (histogram left-heavy), one overexposed (histogram right-heavy), one balanced (centered). Compare the data and detail in each.

punchline.text: Don't trust the screen. Trust the histogram. It's the truth about your exposure.

quiz.question: What does data pushed against the right wall of a histogram indicate?
